The Wells\’ score is a number that reflects your risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Using this score, your doctor can determine your likelihood of having DVT. This helps your doctor decide whether to proceed with further diagnostic testing, such as a CT scan.

Photoplethysmography (PPG) is a simple and low-cost optical technique that can be used to detect blood volume changes in the microvascular bed of tissue. It is often used non-invasively to make measurements at the skin surface*.

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a serious condition that occurs when a blood clot forms in a vein located deep inside your body. A blood clot is a clump of blood that’s turned to a solid state. Deep vein blood clots typically form in your thigh or lower leg, but they can also develop in other areas of your body (Healthline, 2021).

It is important to know about DVT because it can happen to anybody and can cause serious illness, disability, and in some cases, death. The good news is that DVT is preventable and treatable if discovered early (CDC, 2020).

If you have a DVT, it\'s important to get diagnosed right away before it becomes a pulmonary embolism. Once a PE blocks an artery in your lung, all blood flow is reduced or stopped completely, which can cause sudden death.

Your healthcare provider will most likely perform a compression ultrasound, but other tests, like a venogram, CT scan, or D-dimer test, can also be used to diagnose DVT. Through a compression ultrasound, your practitioner is able to see the blood clot and the obstruction of blood flow in the vein.
The VeinView DVT Detector is a device that uses photoplethysmography (PPG) to detect blood volume changes. By detecting blood volume changes, we can determine your risk level of having a DVT.

This PPG test is not a diagnostic test like the ones listed above. That is, it cannot tell you for certain whether or not you have a DVT. However, it does provide accurate information and a risk level without an lengthy trip to the hospital nor expensive medical equipment.

The risk level should be used to determine the necessity of contacting your physician to talk about receiving a diagnostic test for DVT. We would recommend talking to your doctor about a diagnostic test if a red and yellow risk level is evaluated using both the PPG test and the Well\'s Screening Tool in one testing period.
The VeinView DVT Detector performs PPG testing by using an LED infrared light to send light through the skin and a light sensor (photodiode) to catch light reflecting back after hitting the blood.
By reading the changes in light reflection, the device can read approximate levels of bloodflow through the vein. We can use these numbers to calculate DVT risk.
1. Find a chair in which you can sit comfortably and can stretch out your leg with your heel on the floor.
2. Attach your VeinView device about 10cm above your inner ankle joint using a piece of double sided tape
3. Turn on your device to allow it to calibrate to your skin opacity.

4. Once the device is done calibrating, start the device and perform foot flexions and extensions (Keeping your heel on the ground, bring your toes up, then bring them back down). You will perform 10 such foot flexions, about 1 per second.
5. After the 10 motions, relax and try to remain as still as you can.
6. When your device beeps, you may remove the device and read the value. Record this value in the appropriate box below.
7.Repeat steps 1 through 6 for the other leg.

string.u: How Do I Read My Results?

resources.string: Your results for your different tests are recorded in your records screen. On the scrollable list, they display their risk level, the type of test, and the date when the test was taken.
A Green risk level indicates that there is no significant risk of the presence of a DVT. You likely do not need to see a doctor for DVT if you receive a Green rating.
A Yellow risk level indicates that there is a risk of the presence of a DVT. We would suggest that you take the other screening test to further inform your risk level.
A Red risk level indicates that there is significant risk of the presence of a DVT. Once again, we would suggest that you take the other screening test to further inform your risk level.
If two Yellow risk levels are obtained between the two tests, then we would suggest exercising caution and informing your physician at your next visit.
If two Red risk levels or a Red and a Yellow risk level are obtained between the two tests, then we would suggest contacting your physician to request diagnostic testing.

Note: Incorrect placement of the device will negatively affect your readings. Additionally, if you have venous/arterial disorders or a history of them, this may affect your readings. You may need to talk with your doctor about alternative screening methods for your particular condition.
Active cancer (Treatment or palliation within 6 months)
Bedridden recently > 3 days or major surgery within 12 weeks
Calf swelling > 3 cm compared to the other leg
Localized tenderness along the deep venous system
Pitting edema, confined to symptomatic leg
Paralysis, paresis, or recent plaster immobilization of the lower extremity
Alternative diagnosis to DVT as likely or more likely
